I was 15, running around my school in Iran, showing my classmates the trailers for Final Fantasy XV. It made me proud to be a gamer (and future game designer). ‚ÄúThis is what games are! Do you see why I‚Äôm so passionate about this now?‚Äù

Now I‚Äôm 27. A whole decade later, I finally played it. I‚Äôd been scared ‚Äî scared it wouldn‚Äôt live up to what I saw back then. The reviews weren‚Äôt perfect, and that haunted me. But somehow, after all this time, it [i]exceeded[/i] my expectations ‚Äî and that might surprise most people.

This game is genius. Absolute genius ‚Äî maybe even in ways the developers never intended. Maybe that‚Äôs copium. Maybe it‚Äôs truth. But either way, FFXV is about something bigger than itself: the beauty of life and its inevitable passing. It‚Äôs that one last road trip with the boys. The side quests you hated doing at the time ‚Äî fetching tomatoes, running errands ‚Äî somehow become the sweetest memories when it‚Äôs all over.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a king, goddammit!‚Äù you think, "why am I fetching tomatoes for you?". But that‚Äôs the point ‚Äî you had the privilege of knowing normalcy. Like capital-L [i]Life[/i] itself, the small, mundane things end up meaning the most. By the end, you find yourself missing the early hours ‚Äî the stupid fetch quests, the campfires, the jokes and banter with your brothers. What you wouldn‚Äôt give for one more night under the stars with them.

People wanted another [i]Witcher 3[/i] ‚Äî a world bursting with content, where every random joe on every corner had a deep story to tell. But FFXV isn‚Äôt that kind of game, and Life isn't that kind of experience. Its emptiness [i]is the point.[/i] Life isn‚Äôt packed with meaning at every turn; it‚Äôs quiet, awkward, sometimes tedious. And then one day you look back and realize ‚Äî that was it. That was life itself.

You don‚Äôt remember the massive battles. You remember your brothers. The drives. The fireside laughter. The homemade meals. And somewhere along the way, it stops feeling like a game. It feels like a memory.

Maybe I‚Äôm coping. Maybe I‚Äôm seeing something that isn‚Äôt there. But I‚Äôd rather believe it was intentional ‚Äî that the tedium, the melancholy, the silence ‚Äî all of it was designed to make you feel the weight of time. And if you play the game with this perspective, it would reach into the depths of your soul and impact you in a way that no other game has.

Final Fantasy XV is messy, beautiful, and painfully human. As I fight back tears, all I want to say is: Ignis, Gladio, Prompto ‚Äî thank you for living this life with me. You guys... are the best.

When it's good, it's amazing. I recommend watching the movie, Kingsglaive, first (treat it like an extended opening cutscene) as well as the Brotherhood anime on youtube. 

Gameplay-wise, it's a flawed gem. The combat system was refined into the far better system the FFVII remake games currently use, but you can seeds of it here. What this game has that I haven't ever seen done better is the party interactions, both in and out of combat. It's like they took the party banter that Bioware and Naughty Dog were known for in the 2010s and incorporated it into an open world RPG without it feeling repetitive. There's a reason the main 4 characters are consistently regarded as the best part of this game. It's not that the story is bad, it's fractured, but the one part that consistently works throughout the whole game is the party dynamics.

All that to say, the game is a great time if you can tolerate some major flaws that don't disrupt the core of the experience.

Final Fantasy XV was a game that I had heard mixed opinions about, but I entered the game open minded. At it's core, the game is unlike any other game in the Final Fantasy franchise. The open world is vast and well built, offering unique experiences and vastly different landscapes as you progress through the game and travel around the world.

For the most part, the bulk of the game is openly exploring the world and completing quests/levelling up your skills and equipment. And although I like to complete games fully before writing reviews. I could not bring myself to fully complete all achievements before doing so, not because the game is bad. But the pacing of the mid-game is slow, and relies heavily on your willingness to complete all side quests before progressing to the endgame. 

Narratively, I thought the game was interesting, and offered something unique - a lot of the story telling is done through the travelling with your friends on the road, and the feeling of a road trip is something this game excels at. You really feel connected with this group and you start to enjoy the time you spend with them, and watching them live and work together. Conflicts and character development are always key features in Final Fantasy games and this game is no different. The development of the group from the start of the game to the end is remarkable and seeing the bonds form and change in real time is something I thought was well executed. The end game really picks up and for me is largely the best part of the game, in terms of action and outright story telling.

Combat is simple, but effective. I found that it wasn't as complex and extravagant as compared to Final Fantasy XVI but I think it's fun. Working to get ability points and freely choose what to upgrade was a nice change, although I felt like the prices of later upgrades are harder to reach if you're wanting an easy playthrough but if you're willing to put the time in and complete it fully, then you will get everything and you will see just how vast the upgrade system can be.

Quests in the game are largely simple, however the travelling to and from becomes tiring and tedious, with few quests being close by. Although it does encourage exploration, I do think it took away from the overall experience at times, as I would waste an entire day just working on 2-3 quests largely just from travelling.

Visually, I thought the game was stunning, considering the game is a few years old, I thought it held up really well and some areas and cutscenes were incredibly well designed. The music is incredible as always, but that is to be expected with the Final Fantasy franchise. Performance wasn't really an issue, with the game only crashing once for me, which was the last boss fight, but aside from that, I had no issues with performance.

As a whole, I would recommend playing the game, but I will warn that it's one that requires commitment and a willingness to complete it fully, to truly get the most from it.

I'm going to make this brief and just highlight the things that made this game pretty cool and pretty bad and if I could leave this as a mixed review I would. But for what it's worth, it was an okay experience at best and the following will contain spoilers:

Combat-

Pretty okay combat. Playing as Noctis was fun towards the later end of the game and it wasn't even close. Armiger (and Armiger Awakened) were insanely fun to use and the team bar was interesting to try and diversify the strategies for some enemies. Now, it was very and far few between for it to have really mattered (Aoe vs single target) and with the right weapons it was solely just Break and Jump. Gladiolus' gameplay relied a lot on counters and blocking to build stats and unless you're doing a boss battle it was pretty lame outside of his episode. Ignis suffered the same where outside of the elemental daggers, there really wasn't much interesting about his gameplay outside of seeing what you can do with his Clarity mechanic. Prompto easily had one of the more fun gameplay in comparison with his guns (smg, rocket launcher, and grenade) and Crackshot mechanic.

Story -

Okay, this portion is where knowing about Vs XIII and comparing it to the current story it's terrible. But for looking at it solely, the -very- beginning of it is actually what caught all of my attention. Ardyn Izunia is the 'main' protagonist of the game. A benevolent healer that would go around healing the Star Scourge from infected people while harboring the scourge within himself. His little brother Somnus, the would be founder king, usurped his position prematurely by slaying Ardyn's lover, the first oracle, and sealing Ardyn away for two thousand years. Originally Ardyn would be the king but the darkness from curing others was slowly corrupting him and the Crystal denied his claim to the throne. His new task by the gods is to spread darkness and be a sacrificial lamb for the Chosen King to appear one day and banish it all with him as the epicenter.

That right there would've been interesting to expand on, minus the final bit. But we fast forward to present day where Noctis is the chosen king, loses everything; his kingdom, his dad, his lover, etc. Noctis wins the favor of the gods in the form of Final Fantasy summons and needs to be reborn as the Chosen King of Light. Fast forward ten years, he goes to fight Ardyn and sacrifices himself to put him down permanently.

That's the synopsis of the game. It's bad. And unless you play the respective character episodes which is detached from the main game, it'll make less sense. And good luck playing Comrades to understand what happened during the time skip between modern and post time skip. A LOT more is explained in the movies and books or whatever but supposedly Bahamut's also just kinda an instigator. Go figure.

Personal Thoughts -

There's not much I can say about this game. The rewards you get suck and you do need a level of a guide to figure out where some stuff is, unless you intend to dump an ungodly amount of time to find everything yourself. There's a level of city exploration Episode Ardyn introduced where, if we had gotten the ability to fly about and explore freely, this game would've been way, way better. The Regalia's ability to fly is lack luster because you are insanely limited on where you can fly and the controls are limiting.

Just mod it if you intend to have a good time. I normally like to play games vanilla on the first play through but there's just too many quality of life changes you can mod in where you won't feel it to be a hassle. The jumping is clunky, the driving is meh, and the restrictions you get like Armiger weapons draining HP per swing is dumb (even if it makes sense lore wise). 


If you need something to kill time, I guess this is a good option. It's not my first or my last choice.

I normally don't write long reviews but when I read other reviews of Final Fantasy XV Windows Edition, I found some resonance with my own experience.

I initially had mixed feelings about Final Fantasy XV, finding some enjoyable elements despite notable flaws. However, after sinking more hours into this game, I'm revising my opinion to [b]mostly negative[/b]. What started as minor annoyances have revealed themselves to be fundamental design problems that make this game more of a chore than an adventure.

[h2]The Day-Night Cycle[/h2]

The day-night cycle remains one of my biggest frustrations. It feels artificially restrictive. I spend half my time just traveling around, and by the time I complete two or three missions, darkness falls and forces me back to camp. This constant interruption kills any sense of momentum or flow. It really feels like being punished to continue to play the game for more than 50 mins at a time. 

The 30-minute real-time cycle for a full day might sounds like a lot, but due to the catastrophic travel system, which simply doesn't give you enough time to accomplish meaningful exploration or quest chains.

[h2]Side Quests, A Complete Lack of Imagination[/h2]

What I initially described as "everywhere but skippable" has revealed itself to be something far worse‚Äîa complete [b]lack of imagination[/b]. Every NPC delivers endless, repetitive, almost exactly the same side quests. Catching red frogs, then yellow frogs, then whatever color frogs. Collecting potatoes, then onions, beans, then whatever vegetables. Even the cutscenes and animations are EXACTLY IDENTICAL.

The quest design is deliberately obscured too‚Äîsome collectibles are hidden in bushes with absolutely no visual or audio clues. Oh, and did I mention that you have to watch those cutscenes AGAIN AND AGAIN BECAUSE THEY ARE UNSKIPPABLE! They don't even bother to create new stories for NPCs; they just label missions "Help XXX doing YYY AGAIN." 99% of the game's sidequests feel like filler, consisting of nothing more than fetching vegetables, gems, or dog tags with zero narrative substance.

[h2]Travel System[/h2]

The travel mechanics remain a mixed bag with persistent issues. You can teleport to parking spots or use autopilot to quest markers, but the map constantly resets to your current location when switching modes. This makes simple tasks‚Äîlike picking a nearby parking lot, teleporting there, and walking to the mission point‚Äîunnecessarily complicated. Ironically, this manual approach is usually faster than the autopilot system, which speaks to how poorly the convenience features are implemented.

[h2]Maze Design[/h2]

The dungeon and maze design represents another major failure. If you fall off a narrow ledge, you're forced to climb all the way back, then squeeze through a crevice WITH ANOTHER LONG UNSKIPPABLE CUTSCENE, only to fall at another cliff and repeat this tedious process.

If I have to give it a score, it would be a [b]3/10[/b]. Beautiful visuals and decent combat can't save this from being a fundamentally flawed experience.

I normally don't write long reviews but when I read other reviews of Final Fantasy XV Windows Edition, I found some resonance with my own experience.

I initially had mixed feelings about Final Fantasy XV, finding some enjoyable elements despite notable flaws. However, after sinking more hours into this game, I'm revising my opinion to [b]mostly negative[/b]. What started as minor annoyances have revealed themselves to be fundamental design problems that make this game more of a chore than an adventure.

[h2]The Day-Night Cycle[/h2]

The day-night cycle remains one of my biggest frustrations. It feels artificially restrictive. I spend half my time just traveling around, and by the time I complete two or three missions, darkness falls and forces me back to camp. This constant interruption kills any sense of momentum or flow. It really feels like being punished to continue to play the game for more than 50 mins at a time. 

The 30-minute real-time cycle for a full day might sounds like a lot, but due to the catastrophic travel system, which simply doesn't give you enough time to accomplish meaningful exploration or quest chains.

[h2]Side Quests, A Complete Lack of Imagination[/h2]

What I initially described as "everywhere but skippable" has revealed itself to be something far worse‚Äîa complete [b]lack of imagination[/b]. Every NPC delivers endless, repetitive, almost exactly the same side quests. Catching red frogs, then yellow frogs, then whatever color frogs. Collecting potatoes, then onions, beans, then whatever vegetables. Even the cutscenes and animations are EXACTLY IDENTICAL.

The quest design is deliberately obscured too‚Äîsome collectibles are hidden in bushes with absolutely no visual or audio clues. Oh, and did I mention that you have to watch those cutscenes AGAIN AND AGAIN BECAUSE THEY ARE UNSKIPPABLE! They don't even bother to create new stories for NPCs; they just label missions "Help XXX doing YYY AGAIN." 99% of the game's sidequests feel like filler, consisting of nothing more than fetching vegetables, gems, or dog tags with zero narrative substance.

[h2]Travel System[/h2]

The travel mechanics remain a mixed bag with persistent issues. You can teleport to parking spots or use autopilot to quest markers, but the map constantly resets to your current location when switching modes. This makes simple tasks‚Äîlike picking a nearby parking lot, teleporting there, and walking to the mission point‚Äîunnecessarily complicated. Ironically, this manual approach is usually faster than the autopilot system, which speaks to how poorly the convenience features are implemented.

[h2]Maze Design[/h2]

The dungeon and maze design represents another major failure. If you fall off a narrow ledge, you're forced to climb all the way back, then squeeze through a crevice WITH ANOTHER LONG UNSKIPPABLE CUTSCENE, only to fall at another cliff and repeat this tedious process.

If I have to give it a score, it would be a [b]3/10[/b]. Beautiful visuals and decent combat can't save this from being a fundamentally flawed experience.

(SPOILERS) Final Fantasy XV is such a frustrating game because you want it so badly to be a great game, but it's so frustratingly mediocre and directionless that after playing it for about 13 hours, I had to put it down.

The first 2 hours of the game are nothing less than amazing, you are introduced to 4 characters through a dialogue oozing with chemistry, and are shown an open world that leaves so much to the imagination. The sprawling landscapes and beautiful views that bring you to say: "wow, this world is beautiful, I can't wait to see what comes next."

Those first 2 hours were the best hours of the game, and it wasn't even close.

Then comes the big twist in the story: the city in which you start the game in is taken under siege by the evil faction in the game, and your father, king Regis, is killed in the onslaught. Our main character, Noctis, is obviously devastated by this. The news comes out of nowhere, for both the player and the characters, and hits him like a truck; but I hadn't had a single emotional connection with the city or the late king, I hadn't even remembered their names before I looked them up on wikipedia. I had no attachment to the inciting incident of the game, because all I knew of the city and person that were destroyed was encompassed all in a three or four minute cutscene at the beginning of the game.

Then comes the fact that the game cannot decide what tone it is trying to go for. Does it want to be a coming-of-age-story of 4 close friends exploring the world and having fun moments with each other? Or does it want to be a serious narrative about the fall of an empire and how that impacts people? Final Fantasy 15 decides to be some weird mix of the two, with seemingly heavy and emotional moments being interjected by one of the characters wanting to go see chocobos. More offensive, however, was when a character left your party for a reason he left unexplained, seemingly going on some great task that he needed to do. A few minutes after he finally reunites with your party, he grabs your attention and you're expecting him to talk about whatever task he felt so obligated to do or at least some comment about how he's feeling, and instead of doing anything like that, he gushes about the (sponsored!) cup-noodles that he loves so much. 

It's not the moment itself that struck me, moreso that there are so many moments like that, where I am internally begging for the game to characterize these people on a deeper level, but it can't decide on what tone it wants to stick with, so any real development of these characters are just interrupted by 'funny haha' moments that bring anything serious to a complete halt.

Like I said, I can excuse a rough story if the gameplay is good enough, but after 12 hours, I genuinely can't find any more fun in this game.

The world is easily the strongest part of the game. There were views while I was driving in which the characters had dialogue something along the lines of "look at that view! it's amazing!", and they were right, the world in this game is beautiful and for the first few hours I was gawking at everything I was seeing. It carried me through my playthrough and was the only thing that beckoned me to explore the world, but a world so large had so little to do inside of it. 99 out of a 100 times, the only content of the open world I could find were fetch quests-- kill these 5 monsters, go get this item and bring it back to me. There was nothing to do in a world brimming with potential. The only memorable quest I had was going to the chocobo ranch, and finding out that there was a monster scaring off the chocobos. The spectacle alone of the time building up to finally finding that monster, seeing its sheer size as you trail it to its den, and the final fight that wraps it all up, was the single most memorable thing I did in that game.

The side content itself kept me from exploring the world, as when I tried a few of them, they were so boring and uninteresting that I found myself just sticking with the 'hunt' quests, which just had you going to a certain location and killing a few monsters for a couple rewards. After a few hours in the game, I was entirely unmotivated to explore the open world in the open world game in favor of just doing a couple fetch quests until I got what I needed.

The biggest gripe I have with this game, however, is the combat system. I'm not one for extreme depth in combat, I'm okay with some things, like combos, being simplified for the player; but the extreme length to which the game tightens its leash on you with how dumbed-down the games systems are is incredibly frustrating. There are many smaller problems I have with the combat, but there are two main things: for one, you can win just about any battle by holding left click and shift, as the game will both auto-target the enemies on your screen and also automatically perform combos entirely out of your own control, taking any agency you could possibly have out of your own battles, you're basically just watching someone else play the game for you. Second, you'll never lose a battle in your life because the healing system is so unbalanced that you can brave any fight through sheer force of potion-spamming, because the game both gives you invulnerability when you've been knocked down AND pauses when you enter item-select so you have all the time in the world to select a healing potion which can put you right back into the fight. This action RPG has no real action, you're just watching people fight while barely having any input of your own. It's a test to see how long you can wait until the fight finally ends after spamming potions and holding two buttons, because the chance of you dying is nonzero, but it's so low that it may as well be nonexistent.  

I really wanted to like this game. It was my second final fantasy game, I played the first one after the collection was on sale, and it had so much promise, but I found myself losing all interest in continuing before I could even finish the game. If you want an Action RPG with a developed and interesting world, play Elden Ring, not this.

I normally don't write long reviews but when I read other reviews of Final Fantasy XV Windows Edition, I found some resonance with my own experience.

I initially had mixed feelings about Final Fantasy XV, finding some enjoyable elements despite notable flaws. However, after sinking more hours into this game, I'm revising my opinion to [b]mostly negative[/b]. What started as minor annoyances have revealed themselves to be fundamental design problems that make this game more of a chore than an adventure.

[h2]The Day-Night Cycle[/h2]

The day-night cycle remains one of my biggest frustrations. It feels artificially restrictive. I spend half my time just traveling around, and by the time I complete two or three missions, darkness falls and forces me back to camp. This constant interruption kills any sense of momentum or flow. It really feels like being punished to continue to play the game for more than 50 mins at a time. 

The 30-minute real-time cycle for a full day might sounds like a lot, but due to the catastrophic travel system, which simply doesn't give you enough time to accomplish meaningful exploration or quest chains.

[h2]Side Quests, A Complete Lack of Imagination[/h2]

What I initially described as "everywhere but skippable" has revealed itself to be something far worse‚Äîa complete [b]lack of imagination[/b]. Every NPC delivers endless, repetitive, almost exactly the same side quests. Catching red frogs, then yellow frogs, then whatever color frogs. Collecting potatoes, then onions, beans, then whatever vegetables. Even the cutscenes and animations are EXACTLY IDENTICAL.

The quest design is deliberately obscured too‚Äîsome collectibles are hidden in bushes with absolutely no visual or audio clues. Oh, and did I mention that you have to watch those cutscenes AGAIN AND AGAIN BECAUSE THEY ARE UNSKIPPABLE! They don't even bother to create new stories for NPCs; they just label missions "Help XXX doing YYY AGAIN." 99% of the game's sidequests feel like filler, consisting of nothing more than fetching vegetables, gems, or dog tags with zero narrative substance.

[h2]Travel System[/h2]

The travel mechanics remain a mixed bag with persistent issues. You can teleport to parking spots or use autopilot to quest markers, but the map constantly resets to your current location when switching modes. This makes simple tasks‚Äîlike picking a nearby parking lot, teleporting there, and walking to the mission point‚Äîunnecessarily complicated. Ironically, this manual approach is usually faster than the autopilot system, which speaks to how poorly the convenience features are implemented.

[h2]Maze Design[/h2]

The dungeon and maze design represents another major failure. If you fall off a narrow ledge, you're forced to climb all the way back, then squeeze through a crevice WITH ANOTHER LONG UNSKIPPABLE CUTSCENE, only to fall at another cliff and repeat this tedious process.

If I have to give it a score, it would be a [b]3/10[/b]. Beautiful visuals and decent combat can't save this from being a fundamentally flawed experience.

(SPOILERS) Final Fantasy XV is such a frustrating game because you want it so badly to be a great game, but it's so frustratingly mediocre and directionless that after playing it for about 13 hours, I had to put it down.

The first 2 hours of the game are nothing less than amazing, you are introduced to 4 characters through a dialogue oozing with chemistry, and are shown an open world that leaves so much to the imagination. The sprawling landscapes and beautiful views that bring you to say: "wow, this world is beautiful, I can't wait to see what comes next."

Those first 2 hours were the best hours of the game, and it wasn't even close.

Then comes the big twist in the story: the city in which you start the game in is taken under siege by the evil faction in the game, and your father, king Regis, is killed in the onslaught. Our main character, Noctis, is obviously devastated by this. The news comes out of nowhere, for both the player and the characters, and hits him like a truck; but I hadn't had a single emotional connection with the city or the late king, I hadn't even remembered their names before I looked them up on wikipedia. I had no attachment to the inciting incident of the game, because all I knew of the city and person that were destroyed was encompassed all in a three or four minute cutscene at the beginning of the game.

Then comes the fact that the game cannot decide what tone it is trying to go for. Does it want to be a coming-of-age-story of 4 close friends exploring the world and having fun moments with each other? Or does it want to be a serious narrative about the fall of an empire and how that impacts people? Final Fantasy 15 decides to be some weird mix of the two, with seemingly heavy and emotional moments being interjected by one of the characters wanting to go see chocobos. More offensive, however, was when a character left your party for a reason he left unexplained, seemingly going on some great task that he needed to do. A few minutes after he finally reunites with your party, he grabs your attention and you're expecting him to talk about whatever task he felt so obligated to do or at least some comment about how he's feeling, and instead of doing anything like that, he gushes about the (sponsored!) cup-noodles that he loves so much. 

It's not the moment itself that struck me, moreso that there are so many moments like that, where I am internally begging for the game to characterize these people on a deeper level, but it can't decide on what tone it wants to stick with, so any real development of these characters are just interrupted by 'funny haha' moments that bring anything serious to a complete halt.

Like I said, I can excuse a rough story if the gameplay is good enough, but after 12 hours, I genuinely can't find any more fun in this game.

The world is easily the strongest part of the game. There were views while I was driving in which the characters had dialogue something along the lines of "look at that view! it's amazing!", and they were right, the world in this game is beautiful and for the first few hours I was gawking at everything I was seeing. It carried me through my playthrough and was the only thing that beckoned me to explore the world, but a world so large had so little to do inside of it. 99 out of a 100 times, the only content of the open world I could find were fetch quests-- kill these 5 monsters, go get this item and bring it back to me. There was nothing to do in a world brimming with potential. The only memorable quest I had was going to the chocobo ranch, and finding out that there was a monster scaring off the chocobos. The spectacle alone of the time building up to finally finding that monster, seeing its sheer size as you trail it to its den, and the final fight that wraps it all up, was the single most memorable thing I did in that game.

The side content itself kept me from exploring the world, as when I tried a few of them, they were so boring and uninteresting that I found myself just sticking with the 'hunt' quests, which just had you going to a certain location and killing a few monsters for a couple rewards. After a few hours in the game, I was entirely unmotivated to explore the open world in the open world game in favor of just doing a couple fetch quests until I got what I needed.

The biggest gripe I have with this game, however, is the combat system. I'm not one for extreme depth in combat, I'm okay with some things, like combos, being simplified for the player; but the extreme length to which the game tightens its leash on you with how dumbed-down the games systems are is incredibly frustrating. There are many smaller problems I have with the combat, but there are two main things: for one, you can win just about any battle by holding left click and shift, as the game will both auto-target the enemies on your screen and also automatically perform combos entirely out of your own control, taking any agency you could possibly have out of your own battles, you're basically just watching someone else play the game for you. Second, you'll never lose a battle in your life because the healing system is so unbalanced that you can brave any fight through sheer force of potion-spamming, because the game both gives you invulnerability when you've been knocked down AND pauses when you enter item-select so you have all the time in the world to select a healing potion which can put you right back into the fight. This action RPG has no real action, you're just watching people fight while barely having any input of your own. It's a test to see how long you can wait until the fight finally ends after spamming potions and holding two buttons, because the chance of you dying is nonzero, but it's so low that it may as well be nonexistent.  

I really wanted to like this game. It was my second final fantasy game, I played the first one after the collection was on sale, and it had so much promise, but I found myself losing all interest in continuing before I could even finish the game. If you want an Action RPG with a developed and interesting world, play Elden Ring, not this.
